div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, January 4, 1897
div1.p:
I was glad
to get your letter
this evening. Announcing
your safe arrival
at Hatley. It was
very nice to meet the
Baltimore people at
Springfield. I hope
you will have good
weather now at Hatley
It is beginning to
get warm here,
and the regular
afternoon thunderstorms
have started in.

I am busier than ever
now at the hospital.
On Monday I am
to take a special
student for three weeks
a physician from the
south for which I
am to receive a
very welcome $50.

General Seth tells me there is
a chance of getting the plaintiff
in the sail to accept $250
if we drop the case now.

Mr. Poe charges only $50. General
Seth says he will take nothing
but I think it best to insist
on his taking $50.

I just read Mrs. Humphrey Ward's
“Sir George Tressody.” It is very
good indeed, better than “Marcella”.
You should read it, if they have
it in the library.

Mom has not yet put in an
appearance but we get along
very well with the girl we
have. She is more presentable
than Mom but she is not
so reliable. She
generally forgets what
she is told to do.

There are no signs
of Uncle Tom coming.

I am very glad
I went on to see
you at New York.
